ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Sharpened writing and secondary source analysis

I developed a knowledge of debates in western political philosophy about the relations between states and the philosophical foundations of international law. I was taught to contextualize these debates historically by understanding their relationship with the transition from empires to nation-states.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an incredible course. The syllabus was fantastic. Every reading was insightful and opened up new vistas of understanding. The assignments were targeted and effective, and never overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think there are unfortunately more engaging classes for learning about political theory.

I highly recommend the course. It provides extremely important knowledge that one cannot find by reading current political theory about international relations because that work is not historically grounded. After taking the course, I feel prepared to critique this scholarship and to write more nuanced historical scholarship about the topics we discussed. It provided new lenses for thinking about important political problems including international law, trade, globalization, decolonization, and more.
